1.content:
Hannah Denny and Luis Armstrong have been friends since before they started school, when their mothers would talk with each other, and let them play in the living room.
They could talk to each other about anything on their minds. Hannah would talk to him about her friend problems, her problems with guys, and Luis would talk to her about her girl problems, and things about his buds. They felt so comfortable talking about anything, except for the feeling that they were getting when they were around each other...alone.

Their feelings became aware when they were in their junior year of high school. He had noticed her curvey figure, her breasts, her full, thick brunette hair, for what seemed like the first time. Her happy, sweet attitude to go with it. She had noticed his cute dimples, his deep brown eyes that show out from his deep black hair, and smooth deep tan skin. His toned, muscular skin, and the way he cared about her when she needed his input. These were the things they seemed not to have noticed before, but it was like a curtain had been closed before their eyes, and now they had opened, revealing everything they had to show each other.
1.title: The Opened Curtain

You can watch t.v. if you want, or stay up here," Hannah said as she walked over to where her private bathroom was. "You know, you're lucky to have your own bathroom," Luis said. "Yeah well, sometimes it isn't always my private bathroom, when Josh comes in here. That lil snot," Hannah said with an annoyed expression on her face. Josh was Hannah's eleven year old brother.

Luis stood up, and looked over at her cheerleading pictures. Hannah had become captain of the squad, and he knew she deserved it. She had been cheerleading since he could remember. That's what she had always wanted to be. His gaze shifted from her cheerleading pictures, to pictures of her and him, and just of her, and just of him. Some were even of her and her previous boyfriend. They had been going out for such a long time. He thought to himself, as he kept staring at that particular photo.

When he saw the photo's of them when they were young, he relized she was a cutey, even back then. He found some of her cheerleading trophies, and a track and field award, when she was in the ninth grade. She had quit track and field after that. He didn't know why, he never even thought of asking her either.

When she came out of the shower, she had a towel wrapped around her. He couldn't help but stare. "What are you looking at?" She asked kiddingly. Was she flirting with him? He wondered. Yeah right, she's your best friend, not your girlfriend. "Uh-nothing. You just surprised me. That's all," He covered. "Oh. Well, I'll be a few minutes. I just have to get dressed, do my hair and teeth. You want to shower? I still have some of your clothes over here," She said holding the clothes she had picked up, close to her. He thought about it for a moment. "Sure. Why not. Don't want to have to make two trips,"

Luis sat on the toilet, with his pants on, and holding his shirt. He couldn't believe what had just happened in her room! He had seen her with no clothes. She had such a figure! He had felt so embarrassed afterward. He hurried, and put on his shirt, and took a comb from her drawer, and quickly combed his hair.

Looking very suitable for the coming winter weather. "Well, you're quick," He said. She smiled and grabbed a jacket. "You probably won't need one," He said. "Oh, okay. Don't forget to get your stuff," She said, her voice sounded kinda shaky. Was it what had happened?

They walked down the stairs, and they walked across the street, and a couple of houses down, and over to his beaten Chevy. She got into the passenger side of the car, and Luis put his jacket, and football gear into the trunk. Then climbed into the car, and revved the engine. "Ready?" He said. 11111111.content:
Luis pulled into the half full parking lot of Brenda's Diner. "And this is a friday. I think this is the deadest friday I've seen in awhile," Hannah said, unbuckling her seatbelt, and opening the door. "Yeah, I know," He said opening his door, and getting out. For some reason, he had an urge to open her door, but didn't because of two reasons, one, she had already opened hers, and two, it would've felt a little akward to do so. He shut his door, and followed Hannah into the diner.

There wasn't any booths by the window open, so they found one in the back. She took a menu, and opened it. "Have any ideas of what you're going to get?" He asked. She wasn't very sociable this evening. He figured it was what had happened in her room. Was she beginning to feel weird around him? He hoped not. She was his best friend, and even though his friends said that she would be a hell of a better girlfriend than a best friend. He knew they were wrong. She had been there for him, when he had broken his arm back two years ago. He had been there for her, when she broke her leg when she had tripped over her brother Josh's toy. They had been there more times for each other, than any other best friend couple that he knew of.

"Uh...I think I'm going to have a cheeseburger, french fries, and a chocolate shake," She replied, with a sigh at the end. "What's wrong Hannah?" He said finally, feeling a pressure inside of him, lessen, until it was gone. She looked at him, her large blue eyes, staring at him. "What do you mean?" She said finally. "Well, you haven't said more than like ten words since after we kissed in your room," He said. "Well, that wasn't exactly how I wanted to spend having a kiss. I mean, we just got done accidentally showing our selves in the nude," She replied. She ran her hand through her hair, something she did when she was nervous. She never bit her nails, or itched herself, it was always running her hand through her hair. He didn't know why, but maybe it was a way of her way of not showing she was nervous, even though she was. "I'm sorry, I just...I don't know. It felt weird for me too, you know," He said, hoping that would make her feel a little bit better.

"Can we forget it? I don't like arguing with you," She said. When she was done, a waiter came over, and took their order. They thanked him, and he tried to find something else to talk about. "When is your next practice?" He asked. "Tomorrow. We have a game Monday. Who is it against? The Falcons?" She asked. She folded her hands and placed them on the table. "No, it's against the Warriors," He replied. "Oh. We'll kick their asses. They are the only team that hasn't won a game, and there are like only four games left," She said with a smile when she was talking about kicking their asses. It was rare to hear her swear. Maybe him, when he was around his buds, but when he was just him and around Hannah, he didn't. It was even a shock when she said 'asses'. "Yeah. They haven't won a championship since like 92, and that was because the Falcons had just lost their coach, and their minds were on other things," He said. "I'll be right back. I have to go use the little girl's room," She said, excusing herself from the table, and walking across the floor, to the otherside of the room, where the restrooms were located.

I was silently praying that she would turn back, that we could spend a few more precious moments together. I watched as she slowly walked down the street. 1132.content:
Speeding down the street, Luis found himself checking his reflection in the rear view mirror, repeatedly. When he caught himself the third time, he shook his dark hair out of his eyes, narrowing them to slits.

"Get it together, man." He muttered to himself in irritation. "I mean, you know what this girl looked like in diapers, for Christ's sake. What's the big deal?"

A horn blasted abruptly, and bringing his attention back to the road, he slammed on the breaks just before fully running a red light. He put the car into reverse, backing up to the designated line of the intersection. He sat there for a moment, breathing hard, watching the traffic speed by, the interior lit with the red hue of the stoplight.

"So busy talking to yourself, you're gonna get yourself killed." He sighed in disgust, waiting for the beating of his heart to slow down. The light switched to green, and he carefully drove the next few blocks to the Diner.

Pulling in, he glanced around the parking lot, his eyes searching for Hannah's car. It didn't appear as though she had arrived yet. Just as well, he thought, Clear your mind so you can actually hold a decent, normal conversation. He shook his head one last time, took a breath, and stepped out of the car, locking it. Donning his usual confident strut, he strode to the door, and walked inside.

Scanning the vinyl booths, double checking to make sure she hadn't arrived, he slid into booth number eleven, their table. The waitress appeared promptly, placing the plastic coated menu before him.

"How's it goin'?" she asked, her gum popping loudly, one hand resting on her slim hip.

"Pretty good, pretty good. How 'bout you, Cat?"

"Ah, same shit, different day, ya know what I mean?" Cat winked, tossing her blonde ponytail over her shoulder.

"Yeah," he laughed. "I do. I'm waiting for someone, could I just get a Coke for now?"

"Sure thing." she leaned forward a bit. She smelled of cheap perfume and french fries. "Say, ya gotta date?" She whispered in a conspiring tone.

"No," he laughed again, this time a bit nervously, and glanced around the diner. She spoke softly, but it didn't diminish the feeling he suddenly had of being in a spotlight. "No," he said again, "I'm meeting Hannah."

"Oh right. Hannah." Leaning back, Cat surveyed his face, her blue eyes searching. "Your friend Hannah." She nodded, smiling slightly. "By the look on your face, hon, I think I better be gettin' you that Coke." She winked again before sauntering off.

Luis gave a sigh of relief. First his mother, and now this. As if he weren't nervous enoug- no! he wasn't nervous! He wiped his sweaty palms down his thighs. Maybe I'm coming down with something.

He propped his elbows up on the table, steepling his fingers under his chin. You've got to figure this out. A voice in his mind insisted. Figure what out? There's nothing to figure out! Hannah is my best friend! No teenage hormones are going to ruin that friendship for me!

Is it really only hormones? The voice persisted. What if this is the love of your life? Why can't you get her out of your head?

Why can't I get this voice out of my head!He shouted back at it. The love of my life? I'm only sixteen! Give me a break! The fact of the matter is this, Hannah is my best friend. I would die if I lost her. I am not going to risk that. For anything. No way.

"We're just friends!" He shouted. Abruptly the room went quiet, silent but for the sound of the Musak playing softly. He looked around, and sunk deeper into the booth. Across the room, Cat caught his eye, and jerked her head to the side, in gesture toward the door right behind him.

In a slow deliberate movement, he turned. Hannah was standing there, having just walked in. He wasn't sure, who could read a womans face, when haven't you been able to read Hannah's face?, the voice in his head asked sardonically; but he thought he caught a hurt expression crossing it, before it smoothed out. She finished the short walk to the table, sliding in across from him.

"You know, talking to yourself is said to be a sign of impending mental collapse." She grinned. Was it his imagination, or did that smile seem a bit tight? He waited for her to ask who he was "just friends with." His hands broke out into another sweat.

"That's what they say." He answered, after a long moment. He almost breathed an audible sound of relief, when Cat approached, placing his soda before him.

"Hey sweetie." She smiled at Hannah. "What can I getcha to drink?" Hannah's eyes rested on his face for a moment, penetrating, before she turned to the waitress.

"I'll just have Coke too. Actually, a vanilla Coke. Thanks."

"Comin' right up." Cat stood for one extended moment, looking between the two of them, before her grin widened, and she walked away, glancing once behind her.

He looked at Hannah. Opened his mouth. Closed it. What the hell is your problem, man? Opened it again.

"So..." he said, and grinned at her, as the same syllable drifted from her mouth simultaneously. Her beautiful mouth. She giggled.

"Jinx! This Cokes' on you!"

"Guess you got me..." he replied.

Silence. Isn't it funny how two seconds can seem like an eternity sometimes? he thought. You've got to get past this attraction, or your going to lose her as friend anyway. She doesn't want to hang out with a bore.

Just then, he saw her glance past him. "What's up?" he asked.

"The gang's just showed up." she responded, looking back to him, her blue eyes deep and mesmerizing. For a moment, he thought he saw the same look on her face as when she walked in, the hurt, combined with a certain questioning....

Turning slightly, he saw a group of their friends from school crowding into a table, laughing.

"Do you think we should join them?" He asked slowly, watching her face carefully.

'Luis? have nt hrd from u in so long, i miss u. please say ur still around! i couldn't find ur online profiles. listen i've moved bac 2 town, it's a long story but i want to speak to u and hann. scarl. xxx'

Luis abandonsthe phone to continue driving. It's odd that she had moved back- when she had started her new school, she had raved about her new friends and teachers and house.

As he pulls up in front of the house, he picks up his phone again and quickly texts back,

'nice to hear from you, it's been so long, where do you want to meet?'

"Luis?" the voice is familiar.

Luis glanced outside- his mother stands there, next to someone else. He opens the door and stands up.

"Luis, it's Scarlet. It's been so long! She wants to talk to you."

A girl stands beside Luis's mother. She is small and slim, wrapped up in jeans, boots, a colourful scarf and coat. Her dark auburn hair is slightly longer than shoulder length, blowing slightly in the breeze. She looks just the same- button nose, big green eyes framed by thick lashes and pink lips. The only differences are that she is slightly taller and a shiny silver stud is on her lower lip.

"Scarlet." Luis breathes.

"Luis!" she laughs as his mother steps inside. She envelops him in a warm hug, smelling of peppermint. "I can't believe how different you look!"

"You haven't changed.. so, what are you here for?"

Scarlet shrugged, looking down. "I guess I'll tell you later. Where's Hannah?"

"She's at Ashley's house. You remember Ashley?"

"Yes- not as much as I remember you." Scarlet replied. "I've missed you a lot, you know."

Luis says, surprised, "Didn't think you did- what about all of your friends in your new town?"

Scarlet swallowed, seeming uncomfortable again. Then she smiled, "Tell you later, like I said!"

"Alright," Luis replies, "I know a place two minutes walk from here. You might remember it. It's...
113212.title: Scarlet

1132121.content:
"Okay." Scarlet agrees. "I'd love a hot chocolate.."

Luis quickly alerts his mother, and they begin the walk to the cafe. It's called simply, 'Coffee' and it's a small cosy place smelling of freshly brewed coffee, with squishy cream and chocolate brown beanbags, armchairs and sofas. Vibrant artwork decorates the walls. It's one of Hannah and Luis's haunts.

On the way, Scarlet tells Luis about her life since moving away- she lived in a four bedroom house with her mom, older sister Rachael, younger brother James and labrador Eddie. It was situated beside a field of horses and five minutes away from a busy town and school.

"It sounded perfect." Scarlet sighs, as Luis pushes open the door to the cafe. "But it wasn't. That's why I'm back, we're moving into an old house on the edge of town. It's a bit tight as I have to share with Rachael, but I'm just happy to be away from there." she shudders.

Scarlet sits on an armchair next to the window as a light rain starts to fall, requesting a hot chocolate and oatmeal cookie. Luis goes to order- behind the counter is Hailey, Hannah's sister, older by a year.

"Hey, Luis." she says. "Thought you were going to be with Hannah today?"

"Yeah, I was." Luis says, stating his order. "But she went to a party and I just wasn't in the mood.

Scarlet hears. "Hey, a party? You just told me she was at Ashley's. We should go!"

"Wait, are you.. Scarlet?" Hailey peers out from behind the coffee counter. "I remember you. It's Hailey."

Scarlet smiles, "I remember you, too. It's so weird to see everyone again- I feel like I'm slotting right back in..."

Five minutes later, Hailey places a hot coffee, steamy hot chocolate and a crumbly oatmeal cookie on the table and leaves to clean up the back. That is when Scarlet starts explaining.

Luis sips his coffee while Scarlet stirs the pink marshmallow around in her chocolaty drink. "Those friends I told you about. They weren't as amazing as I made them out to be." she admits. "See, the first one I met was Charlie- he was such a sweetheart." She turns to look outside at the downpour. "Smart, cute, funny. What more could I have asked for? He wasn't all I thought he was, though. He introduced me to his best friends- Georgia," she spat, "a back-stabbing bitch. Elysia," she growled, "the perfect pretty one. Malcolm," she hissed, "the arrogant handsome guy. They all seemed like people I could be best friends with. But they turned on me. In days I got a text telling me to watch my back. The next morning at school someone tripped me up, and that evening Georgia sent me to the wrong class. That night, Malcolm made up a rumour that I slept with some guy I'd never even met." she takes a chunk from her cookie. "But it got worse. The day after, Elysia invited me to her birthday party. I was flattered, but nervous. I got all dressed up and ready but guess what? She gave me the wrong time so when I arrived they could pelt me with water balloons."

"Oh," Luis sighs, sympathetic. "Sorry, Scarlet. Why didn't you say?"

"I didn't want to look pathetic." she replies. "That wasn't how bad it got though. A week later, a week full of taunts and whispering and being tripped up, Charlie called. He asked me to meet him after school with his other friends. I don't know why I thought it would be fine, but I agreed." she sips her hot chocolate, and Luis notices her tear-filled emerald eyes. "I.. I.."

"What happened?" Luis asks.

"I was raped." Scarlet whispers. "They beat me, and I was raped." tears slide down her cheeks. "and they did it the week after that, and every week until I started getting a lift home. For so long I had to endure threatening texts, set-ups. I dreaded school. I tried to end it once." Scarlet is crying into her hot chocolate now. "I needed to leave. I'll never go back, I'll never go back!" she buries her head in her hands, and Luis goes to the other side and sits on the side of the armchair to comfort her. He holds her hand and puts his arm around her shoulder as she blubs.

"I'm sorry for not being there for you, Scarlet."

"That's okay," she sniffs, "you didn't know." as Luis's phone rings. He glances down- Hannah.

Luis glanced in at the cafe from where he stood outside. Scarlett was shifting in her seat, biting her lip. She looked worried. It was still raining, harder now, and Luis slipped into the doorway. There could be a lot of traffic, and could he really just abandon Scarlett after her confession?

Luis raked his hand through his hair in frustration.

"What did he do, Hannah?"

"I.. just, come here, okay? I need you to pick me up." Hannah said quietly, voice slightly wavering. Luis could hear a couple of shouts in the background.

Hannah can be a drama queen sometimes. Luis thought. Probably just some loons she doesn't like hanging around. She'll be fine.

A sudden burst of anger rose inside him.

"Sorry, Hannah, maybe you should just deal with him yourself. Have you ever thought I could be busy, thinking about anything besides you? Well, I am busy, not anticipating your call so I can hang on your every word. I'm sure there's other people that can pick you up." He pressed down hard on the 'end call' button- instantly regretting what he had just said.

Why did I say that, why did I say that?

He stared at the phone, rushing back into the contacts list and finding Hannah. His finger rested on the call button.

Luis held Scarlet in his arms, her head nestled into his chest. He put pressure on the off button at the top of the Sonny Erix X20 and slid it back into his pocket.

Hailey ran back to the table, her short, ebony pixie bob bouncing, the blue of her eyes stinging with panic. 'We've got to go. Like now. Scar, I'll drop you off at home. Come on.' Hailey was eighteen, always straight talking, effective and trustworthy with secrets but this left a sick feeling in Luis' throat. What had happened that Hannah had called him for and he had mindlessly ignored it?

The green Mercedes four by four loomed above them.

Hannah's mother ran past them towards the counter. H

113212122.content:
Hannah's mother- Rose- turned, and stopped.

"Hailey." she reached forward and gave her daughter a hug. 'I've been so worried..' she then wrapped Luis in a warm embrace. 'Oh, Luis, I'm so happy you're here. I'm sure Hannah will be glad to see you.' She squeezed his hand, smile warm, but eyes full of worry.

Hailey immediately turned to the pen-chewing brunette sitting behind the desk. 'Where can we find Hannah Denny?'

The girl, who already had the answer ready from Rose's desperate request, replied. Luis felt a feeling of dread creep in as Hailey and Rose looked at each other and began to walk briskly. What if she's not okay? he wondered, as he began to follow Hannah's mother and sister.

The smell of disinfectant pervaded Luis's nostrils. They moved through the corridors, slipping past busy nurses and doctors. After going up, then down, then up another two floors and walking to what must have been the other end of the hospital, Luis felt sick with worry. He was also exhausted, and confused, and regretful. It wasn't a good combination.

"Well, here we are.' Rose and Hailey's brisk walk slowed as they reached it. The last door. They grasped each other's hands. Just as a feeling of being left out set in, Rose held out hers. The worry on their faces made Luis feel even more anxious.

There were murmurs coming from inside the door. Rose stepped inside first, followed by Hailey. Luis trailed behind, eyes searching the room.

There she was. Hannah lay, looking as fragile as a doll, on the bed. Her hair was spread out on the pillow, her skin pasty. A bandage was wrapped around her head.

In a plastic blue chair, Lucas sat, cradling her hand. Hannah's friends Megan and Elle hung back, rapidly texting and whispering, glancing from Hannah to their phone's screen. They acknowledged Rose, Hailey and Luis's entrance with a nod and a sympathetic smile.

Lucas looked coldly at Luis, and nodded briefly to Hailey and Rose. Then he let go of Hannah's hand and stepped back against the wall.

"That sounds nice." Scarlet sighs. She links arms with Luis as they begin to stroll towards the park, which is nearly visible from the house.

"You know," she says, "I feel so comfortable with you already, which is weird, since it's been so long." she leans closer. "But it's like no time has passed."

Luis agrees- but maybe it's just her. Scarlet's so easygoing she could be friends with anyone in an instant. he thinks.

"I can't wait to see Hannah again, too. How is she?"

Luis faces her. "Hannah's great. Y'know, cheerleading and stuff. Being Hannah, I guess."

"Good. Is she still with Lucas?"

"Probably."

"What d'you mean?" Scarlet laughs. "Surely you know, you and her spend all your time together."

"Well, they did break up a while ago. But she seemed pretty interested in him tonight." he scuffs the hard ground and kicks an empty cola can, thinking about how he looked at her.

Scarlet stops, and Luis turns. "What are you doing?"

"Do you like her?" Scarlet asks, twisting her wool scarf around her fingers. "I always thought you did, you know. Not just like her, but love her. Whenever something happened, Hannah was never to blame." she smiles. "So, do you?"

Luis looks down at his feet, surprised by Scarlet's forwardness. "I.. I.." he glances up, ready to admit it. Scarlet is closer now, standing right in front of him, and a second later her lips are brushing his- softly, but then she kisses him harder. Without thinking, Luis complies. His hand touches her chest, and he can faintly hear her heartbeat as her soft lips move against his.

For a moment, all he can think about is Scarlet- but then Hannah barges into his thoughts. He thinks about how many times he thought, 'I love her.' I do love her. he thinks, as Scarlet hands touch his chest. As soon as this thought formed, he pushes Scarlet away, holding onto only her hands.

"I do love her. I love Hannah." he sighs.

Scarlet's eyes meet his, confused. Then she takes a step back, pushing his hands against his chest. "Oh. I guess you do. Maybe I didn't want to hear it. When you kissed me back, I figured I'd imagined your feelings for her." she runs a hand through her hair, pink creeping into her cheeks. "I'm sorry."

That second, Luis's phone starts to ring. He glances down. "It's Hannah."

"Take it." whispers Scarlet.

Luis flips his phone open and moves a few steps away to answer the call.

"Hey, Hannah, what's up?" he sighs.
"Luis, where are you?" Hannah cries. "I haven't seen you since.. since.. whatever. I really need to talk to you, did you even come to Ashley's?"
"No, I.. I went home. What happened?"
"I want to tell you in person, meet at the park?"
Luis glances to Scarlet. Would Hannah really want to tell Scarlet whatever had happened? It must be serious- Hannah doesn't usually cry about anything, and Scarlet hasn't been a part of their lives in nearly eighteen months.

'Scarlet...'
'You've got to go.' She hissed, her voice sounded coarse and bitter, like shards of glass had been pushed into the back of her throat.

She may have invested her love in him but she had been gone and his love was stitched, embedded and bewitched by Hannah and her innocent smile. He loved saving her. He loved making her smile.

"Ah, home sweet home," Hannah sighed as they walked through the front door, dropping her purse down on a sidetable. She turned to Luis. "I'm gonna get some Pepsi. You want anything?"

"Just water, please," he said, his whole body still tense. 'Just water, please'??? he thought to himself. I sound like I'm at a teaparty!

He could still feel her hand on his. He watched her as she walked away, waiting until she disappeared before he sat down on the stairs, rubbing his hands against his temples. How could she be acting so calm? he wondered frantically. Hadn't she felt... something??? He knew that he certainly had. Feeling like a nervous wreck, he glanced at his reflection in the hallway mirror. He looked a bit like a nervous wreck too.

"Mom? Dad? Anybody home?" he heard Hannah calling as she walked back into the room. She looked at him. "I guess it's just you and me then, buddy ol' pal." She gave him a little grin, and he felt his heart melt. Get a grip!

11322112212.title: Home Alone

113221122122.content:
"Not really," Luis said, scratching his nose, feeling uncomfortable. He... just... didn't want to go outside. Outside, the world was watching. Watching for what? he snapped at himself.

Hannah raised an eyebrow. "Okay then," she said perkily, taking his hand and pulling him up from the stairs. She led him into the living room and let him sit on the couch. "So kiddo, let's watch a movie." He watched her dig through the DVDs on the shelf by the television.

As if anyone would rather watch TV than look at you, he thought. He jumped in his seat, but Hannah didn't notice. Oh my god, what am I thinking? Somebody call the doctor. He stared down at his sneakers, tracing the stitches with his eyes. This was bad.

"Aha," Hannah said, tossing a curtain of cappuccino hair and standing up straight. "Wanna watch Titanic?"

Um, Titanic? The most romantic movie on earth? Luis was feeling more awkward by the minute.

"Well?" Hannah blinked and gave a tiny, puzzled smile at his blank expression.

Luis bit his lip.

"Pleeeeeeease?" Hannah asked, pouting playfully, hugging the movie against her breast.

He gulped, and he wasn't watching her eyes. "Yeah. Okay. Whatever you want, Hannah."

"Yay!" Hannah cried, and turned on the television.

She sank into the couch beside him. Fireworks erupted in Luis's stomach. He could feel his heart thumping in his chest, and boiling blood pulsing through his cheeks. Overall, he felt like he had the flu. Maybe I should go home, he thought, but for some reason he didn't leave. He wouldn't. He couldn't.

They watched the movie, and in one of the most romantic scenes, Hannah looked up a Luis's face. "One of my favorite parts," she whispered.

Is she thinking what I hope she's thinking?

Luis looked into her ocean eyes, and she didn't turn away. Her face was inches away from his. And she wasn't smiling anymore.

121212.content:
"Maybe I shouldn't have..." Were his first words, after the kiss, as he looked down to the floor, unable to face her and meet her beautiful but surely angry eyes. He was going to apologize. He had acted on instinct but he shouldn't have. He might as well be ruining the best friendship he had ever had by being hot-headed and for not being able to control his own feelings.

But he had wanted to kiss her so badly...

"Don't..." He heard her whisper then and he felt her hand raise his chin slightly; he was soon facing her eyes -- and they were shinning brightly, not with anger but... something else... "I... I liked it." She blushed then and Luis had to make a prodigious effort not to take her in his arms and kiss her thoroughly. "You don't have to apologize."

She smiled then and Luis felt himself warm all over. Only Hannah could make him feel like this, an awkward little boy who had just been rewarded with a smile from his dream lady... Was Hannah his dream lady? He stared at her for a long moment, taking in her flowing hair, her glittering eyes, her beautiful nose, her soft skin and that grin on her wonderful lips and he knew... right then and right there... that she was his own dream girl.

They knew so much about each other and still they had never tired of being in each other's presence. They always found new things about each other and had fun reliving their common past. Spent together, most of the times. They were perfect for each other, really. Heck, she knew his parents for ages and they adored her.

But there was always that little voice of his conscience that kept reminding him that if they took that step... if they became more than friends, and it didn't work out, they could loose their friendship and Luis wasn't ready to accept such a thing. But, at the same time, in his heart, he knew they were soulmates...

"Luis?" His thoughts were interrupted by her soft voice, calling to him, a worried frown on her forehead. He smiled at her, his hand caressing her soft cheek gently. He saw her blush again and wondered if he should just leave before this got even more awkward or before he lost any control he might have and kissed her again. He didn't want to go too fast with her... not with Hannah...

Stil... she had said she had liked the kiss...

Well, it wasn't the look itself, really, so much as it was the thoughts that came to mind when he gave her that look... thoughts of silk sheets and incense and...and, well...the events of romance novels...events that made the romance novels look tame, when she added Luis's slender-yet-solid football player's body, his wide, wild smile, his eyes...his...hands...

"And taking my car..."

In his car...with those hands...Hannah stopped herself. What was she thinking? How could she? Then Luis grinned at her again...How couldn't she?

"Out to Vegas and getting hitched. At the Chapel of Love. How 'bout it, baby? Ain't you excited?" Luis was squeezing her hand and giving her a smile that was half affection, a quarter trouble, and a quarter...something else, something...almost serious. Hannah couldn't resist.

She turned doe eyes up to the waitress. "Mmm hmm. We're gonna be together forever and forever! An' in a few months, when Junior's born, we're gonna tell him how romantic the whole weddin' was."

The waitress looked at the two of them like they were nutcases, then she started laughing. "You kids!" she said through her giggles. And then she went to get their food.

"So," Hannah said to Luis, who still hadn't let go of her hand or ankle, "You're eating leaves?"

They walked up to Hannah's front door. Night was creeping up on them, and she still had homework. "Thanks." She replied. She bent down and kissed him on the cheek. "No prob." He replied. She wanted to invite him in, but she figured if she did that, she'd never get to her homework, and she'd get into trouble...again.

"I'll see you tomorrow, at school?" He smiled and walked to the sidewalk. "As always, Hannah." She smiled, but he didn't see it. He had turned, and was jogging across the street.

She turned and walked into the house. The aftersmell of what her parents and brother had for dinner was still lingering in the house. "Did you have fun?" She turned around, and spotted her mother standing in the walkway between the kitchen and the dining room. She nodded. "Of course." Her mother walked into the room. Her brunette hair was up in a ponytail, and so loose strands hung around her face. "I know the two of you are going to become something one of these days. Me and his mother both know it. We can just see the two of you, and your little babies--" Hannah rolled her eyes. "Mother, please. We're friends, and that's all we're going to be." Then why did it sound like a lie to her? It was her mother's turn to roll her eyes. "Keep saying that to yourself." Her mother turned, and walked into the living room.

Hannah sighed deeply, and walked up the stairs, and into her bedroom. She tossed her jacket to the floor, and spread herself across her bed. She pressed her face into the bed, and she wanted to scream. Why did life have to be so complicated? Why couldn't life be more simple, and fun to enjoy? She groaned, and turned around onto her back. She stared at the ceiling, and closed her eyes.

Hannah was still shocked.

"God, this is harder than I ever thought it would be."

"Luis, I don't know...I'm..."

"Sorry I'm being so vague. I'm trying to get out of this with some dignity." He looked down at his lap, heavily exhaling.

"Luis, you know you're one of the most important people to me. If you have something to say, just tell me."

"God Hannah!" Luis raised his voice, an angry glint shining from his eyes. "You're really not making this easy." Luis stood up, threw a couple dollars down on the table, and took a couple steps toward the door.

Hannah sat there, completely stunned. Luis turned around, and walked to the side of the table. He looked down at Hannah.

"Hannah, I think I love you." Luis softly said. "There, happy now?" He turned and walked out of the diner.

12221212221.content:
Hannah blushed and cleared her throat as they opened their menus to order. They really didn't have to look at the menu, as they had been to Brenda's Diner numerous times together -- they memorized each others orders by heart.

They stared at the menu absentmindedly, trying to clear the air, which was full of tension and embarrassment.

"That was weird," Luis finally said, slightly alarming Hannah, who was in deep thought. She took in a sharp breath of air, and her head shot up, eyes slightly wider than usual.

"Uh, yeah," She breathed. "Weird." Finally, they both closed their menus as a waitress approached their booth, and stared at the table uncomfortably.

"So, are you two love-birds ready to order?" The waitress said ecstatically, a huge grin on her heavy-powdered face. Once again, they blushed.

"We're actually not... dating." Hannah quickly responded, trying to make it clear. The waitress looked from one to the other, and her smile faded. After a long uncomfortable silence, she spoke.

"Oh..." she said, and cleared her throat. "Well."

The two teens almost sighed with relief that she had understood and forgot about it.

"It's just that you two look so cute together, and as soon as you walked in, the manager pointed out how adorable a couple you were. You just looked so perfect..." Hannah and Luis stared uncomfortably at each other as the waitress rambled on and on about how perfect they were together, and finally Luis spoke up.

"We're ready to order," he said, interrupting the waitress mid-sentence. She apologized and took their order.

"I'll take a double cheeseburger with extra pickles, with a medium Coke, and she'll have a cheeseburger, plain, with a small Diet Coke..." he said instinctively, as they both knew the order by heart. "We'll also take a large fry, to share."

The waitresses smiled as she jotted down the order, then turned and left. Hannah and Luis looked to each other and smiled nervously. The waitress' words echoed in their head, taunting them and making them sweat. You two look so cute together.... you just looked so perfect...

"I-it's just because we look really close to each other." Luis reasoned, desperate for the right words to say.

"Well, we are really close to each other," Hannah said, almost defensively, "We've been the best of friends since Day One."

The game raged, with Luis winning 24-4. Hannah smirked at herself and shook her head: yeah, the whole team won the game...but without her Luis... The world focused on the number emblazoned on his jersey. 42. A voice in the back of her mind whispered "did you just call him -your- Luis?" 42. Hannah shook her head again. Well yes. Her friend.

She waited outside the locker room for him afterward. In the middle of a conversation with Jimmy, one of the waterboys, she caught a whiff of something clean and damp. Then Luis caught her around the waist and spun her. "How 'bout that, eh, hon?"

Hannah smiled and swatted Luis's arm. "Yeah, you gave 'em heck. Now let me loose and let's go eat."

He set her on her feet, but didn't let her go. The waterboy--what was his name again?--had walked off to talk to one of the cheerleaders, she noticed. Which left her mostly alone with Luis...who still wouldn't let her go...the air got a little thicker. "What if I don't want to let you loose?"

Hannah's pulse tripped. There were worse proposals... "Then you can just carry me to the car. Either way, come on." She tapped halfheartedly at his arm as she hazarded a glance into those cocoa eyes.

He turned her to face him..."Yeah...I'm hungry." The look in his eyes was...positively smoldering. Hannah half hoped he'd move and half hoped he'd kiss her. Kiss her? What? Luis-who-she'd-known-forever kiss her? Still, those eyes...

Hannah realised she'd stopped breathing when a voice behind her made her gasp. It was Mick, a runningback. "Great game, Lou!" he said, pounding Luis's shoulder. Luis shifted his grip on Hannah to free a hand and return the hardy salute.

"You too, Mick. You too."

They watched Mick leave, a bright redhead on his arm. Then Luis shook his head and gave Hannah a one-armed hug that tucked her under his shoulder. "So. On your tab or mine?"

There. That was normal. "I think it's your turn, sport," Hannah answered as they walked out to his car.

************************
They sat in their usual corner booth at Brenda's and had their usual post-game dinner: Five chicken strips for him, and double-large chili cheese fries for her. As always, they ate each other's food as much as they ate their own. As always, they finished half of eachother's sentences. It was easy. It was companionable. It would've been just like sixth grade if she could look at him and not remember the look in his eyes just an hour or two earlier...

A chili bean dropped off her fry as she thought about it; his warm voice--baritone, her year in chorus told her--startled her out of reverie. "You know, those are usually better when you eat them instead of wear them."

She looked down at the bean on her jeans, blushed, speared it with her fork and popped it into her mouth. "Denim's better than salt," she said sheepishly.

"Umm hmm." he replied, one eyebrow up. "Sure." They grinned at eachother across the table, and she wondered what he was thinking.

"I'm thinking it's about time we head out. Your mom'll skin me if I get you home late again."

"I wouldn't worry about it," Hannah said, pushing out of her seat. "I think she likes you more than she likes me anyway."

"It's just 'cause I'm cu-u-u-u-te." Luis teased as he cleaned their table. "Come on."

She snuck glances at him all the way home. Yeah. He was cute. Good thing he was just her best friend; otherwise she'd be as stupid over him as any other girl with eyes should be...
****************

When they got to her house, Luis walked her to the door. "You know, doll, you don't have to do this," she'd said a few weeks ago.
"Yeah I do," he'd answered. "What if the porch monsters got you?"
"That's what the light's for. To keep them away."
"Or to let them see you better. Nah, I'd better walk you up."
She hadn't complained since then. Tonight, her mother had forgotten the porch light. "Uh oh," Luis said in his ooga-booga-boo voice. "Looks like they finally got the light."

"Good thing I've got you to save me from them, then," Hannah answered, feeling strangely flirty. He was her best friend; what was the harm?

"Yeah," he replied. "Good thing..." She could see his half-wild grin in the darkness and felt her pulse start tripping again. "Now who's going to save you from me?" His voice was just light enough, she could take his comment for teasing...but there was something rough around the edges...

"I didn't know I needed saving."

He didn't say anything right then, only pulled her into their usual goodbye hug. She heard him say something, but her ears were muffled in his chest and hand. Then she felt him shake his head, and he let her go. It wasn't till she was mostly asleep that her mind decoded what her ears had half-heard:

"You're right. So who's going to save me from you?"
123.title: Fried food and porch monsters...

1231.content:
Hannah lay awake for hours that night, trying to figure out where her relationship with Luis was going. She was sure he was noticing the same subtle innuendos they had been tossing around for the last few weeks. What had he meant by asking her that strange question, "Who will save me from you"? Why had he even asked it?
"Arrg! This is just too much for me to have to unravel tonight, I must get some sleep!", she had said to herself. She rolled over and pulled the bed covers over her head. Sleep finally came, but would only last three short hours, during which time she would dream of Luis.
Hannah woke smiling the next morning and, not knowing why, jumped out of her bed and raced to find something cheerful to wear for the day. One glance at the clock told her she was going to run out of steam before the day was over, but she shrugged it off. For the moment, she was energized and couldn't wait to get to the school.
It wasn't until she was brushing her teeth that she remembered part of her dream of the night before. It was just a flash of Luis, but he was smiling like she had never seen him smile before. He was saying something to her, yet his mouth uttered nothing. It was more like his eyes were talking and she couldn't quite read what they were saying. Frustrated, she tried harder to remember more of the dream.
They were walking in an immense field of long grass and wildflowers, laughing and teasing each other as they always had. She looked around and realized that Luis was no longer beside her. He had dropped down into the tall grass and was laying on his back with his hands under his head. As she went back to see what he was doing, she realized he was just lying there smiling. She snickered and asked, "Is this going to become a habit with you Luis?" Luis had just continued to smile at the sky with a look of dreamy realization spread across his face. "It just might be Hannah. It seems you have an effect on me that I think I am only just beginning to understand."
1231.title: Understanding

12311.content:
The dream had confuzed her. Hannah didn't know what it meant. Why was she having dreams like this about her best friend? It just didn't make sense. But she didn't have time to figure it out now. She had to get ready for school.

The day went by quickly, but Hannah didn't seem to have gotten much out of any of her classes. She spent the whole day daydreaming about Luis. At lunch she had seem him talking and flirting with one of the popular girls. She had cringed with envy, and then she asked herself why she was so jealous? But when he had looked over at her and winked, she turned around and hurried to her locker.

That evening, Hannah was sitting on her bed doing her homework when the phone rang.
"Hello?"
"Hannah...?"
"Yea. Hey Luis! What's up?" she felt overjoyed just hearing his voice.
"I uhh... need to talk to you."
"Oh yea? About what?" she wondered.
"I don't even know how to begin. It's like.. we've been friends forever, ya know?"
"Yea, sure... since we were toddlers."
"Well... I don't know how to explain this, or how to even start but..." his sentence trailed off.
"But what?"
"I think I'm falling in love with you." Time froze, and neither one of them spoke. Hannah didn't know what to say. For a moment she thought she was dreaming but she pinched herself to assure herself that she wasn't.
"Hannah? Are you still there?"
"Yea, I'm here," she said, barely whispering.
"I, uhh.. didn't mean to freak you out. But I've been having these feelings for weeks now and I've been dieing to tell you. I just didn't know how. You are so beautiful, so sweet, so smart, and so wonderful. You are perfect for me in everyway. A few minutes ago I was lying on my bed thinking about you, and I couldn't take it anymore. I had to tell you. I know you probably don't feel the same way about me but..."
"Luis. Stop talking," Hannah said.
"I'm sorry."
"Don't be sorry. I just wanted to tell you what I was feeling too."
"Really?"
"Yes. Luis... I've been thinking about this for a few days now, you're all I can think about. I love you in more ways that I ever knew possible and you make me feel complete. I have no secrets from you and I've never felt this way about anyone before."
"What are you saying?"
"Let me finish. Luis, what I'm afraid of is that we would something that would be wonderful."
"I don't see what's so horrible about that."
"What if we broke up? Things would just get so wierd. I don't want to loose my best friend, Luis. I don't know if I could live without you in my life."

.................
12311.title: Revealing true feelings

123111.content:
There was a long silence on Luis's end of the line. Then, his voice rougher than it usually was, he asked "Why do you think we'd ever have to break up?"

Hannah blew out the breath she hadn't realised she was holding and shoved a hand through her hair. "I don't know, Luis. But what if? You know? If it did happen, I'd be minus half..." She stopped short, not sure she should say the rest.

"Of my soul." Luis finished for her. "I know. Oh, God, I know. I couldn't stand not having you near me, either. But don't you see that's why we're perfect? I mean, we passed the point of being polite around eachother when we were five. Now, what we see is what we get. And I don't know about you, babe, but I'm.."--he coughed, and Hannah could almost hear him blushing--"I'm pretty into what I see in you."

He sounded so... so Luis. Half sweet, half hot. Heck, all sweet and all hot. Here he was trying to sound like a character in a romance novel with his blush causing static on the phone. How could she resist him? Hannah laughed and knew that he'd hear it for glee instead of ridicule. "I see your point," she answered him between giggles.

Luis laughed a little, too...nervously. "So why don't we give it a go?"

Hannah went silent again..."How about we go on a few dates, ease into the whole situation?"

"Okay. Movies Saturday night sound good?"

"Yeah," Hannah laughed again. "If all else fails..."

"We can play Mystery Science Theatre 3000 with them. So it's a date?"

"...It's a date."

For an hour and a half after she'd hung up the phone, Hannah just sat there with the words "It's a date" going through her head. Oh Lord, she thought, what've I gotten into?
123111.title: Give it a chance...

choices: Hannah finally listens to her heart.
Hannah tries to explain the dream to Luis
1231111.content:
Hannah fell asleep thinking about Saturday-- a night where... something... might happen. If only she knew what she wanted to happen, she'd be set.

..............................

"Hannah, you've got to go for it."

She groaned. Past the empty aquariums to her left, sure enough, it was that insistent talking dog-- a combination of a Beagle and a wire terrier. Sure enough, it was lecturing her. Again.

"I know you think I'm lecturing you--"

"You are."

"--but all this worrying," the dog undeterredly pressed, "is leading you to nowhere, save loneliness."

The last time this dream had recurred was a month ago. Same endless rows of empty fishtanks, same fog, same floor making that same hollow noise with every step, like a gourd hitting cement. The only things missing were--

"Hannah! We, too, think that you should stop worrying about nothing and take a real chance for once in your life!" Sang Jeb Bush and Newt Gingrich, swaying in the wind.

Scratch that; everything WAS here: including the chorus of naked, singing republicans. Hannah made a mental note to figure out what it was she was eating before bed-- this had to stop.

"As I was saying," the dog continued, sniffing at a particularly hairy leg belonging to Bob Dole, "matters of the heart are matters for the heart to decide. Worrying denotes cranial function."

"Cranial function?"

"Is your subconscious the only part of you that pays attention during your high school psychology class?"

"My what class?"

The dog chased its tail in frustration. "Fine. Forget I said anything. JUST STOP USING YOUR BRAIN, FOR HEAVEN'S SAKE!"

As if on cue, the chorus of naked republicans piped in with an eighties song Hannah had heard on the radio. She only remembered part of the lyrics, but she'd gotten the jist of it:

Listen to your heart
And it do do do do
Listen to your heart
And you'll doo do do do

And if nobody answers,
You'll never know!
Listen to your heart
And it comes do doo
...............................

Hannah awoke in a sweat. For as weird as she felt, though, it seemed she'd found the answer she'd been looking for...
1231111.title: Wire Terrier+Republicans=answer.

They had decided to go see Return of the King for the fourth time together, so since they both knew what was going to happen, they could concentrate fully on the awkwardness of sitting next to one another.

Hannah had done this before, she'd launched herself past all the silly weirdness on first dates, but never with her best friend! It was totally unnatural for there to be any awkwardness between them, so she wanted to banish it right away.

"Listen to you heart," Newt Gingrich reminded her, and she nodded decisively.

She leaned over to Luis and whispered close to his ear, "Hey, Luis."

He turned to ask 'what?', but was met instead with a full-on kiss from an emboldened Hannah. She reached up to run her fingers into his curly dark hair and pull him closer, while he overcame his astonishment and put a hand on her hip.

You look up at him and.........

choices: Luis tells her to wait outside
12311121.content:
As she hurried to leave, her mother knocked on the door. "Who is it?" Hannah asked. She looked up, to see her mother's head poking through the open door. "It's mom. Just wanted to tell you to have a good time. Me and Maria have had this thing planned since when we saw Luis try to protect you, when you guys were four. It was so darling," Hannah smiled, and then blushed. "Mom. Please, before I get so embarrassed, I won't be able to go," "Well, it's the truth. You guys are just....so right for each other," Her mother opened the door all the way. "When do you think you'll be back?" Her mother asked. Her mother's name was Abby. "I don't know. I'll call you when the movie gets done. Okay?" Hannah walked over to the door, and stared into her mother's eyes. "Sure. Don't forget, that if I don't see you tonight, that you must watch your brother tomorrow," Hannah sighed. "Okay," Hannah took to the steps, two at a time, and walked out the door.

There were times she liked living in the city. It wasn't directly in the city, but a small suburb outside it. The neighborhoods we good. There wasn't any fights, murders, or fires, unless they just happened from something inside the house. They even have a country look to them. Then there were the times she hated living in the city, or the suburb. She hated not having a large yard, and having the privacy. She lived to deal with it. She has for sixteen years.

She walked slowly over to Luis' house, which was across the street, and three houses down, from the house directly across from hers. He wasn't outside, so she figured he was either still getting ready, or he was waiting for her inside, which was something he never did.

She stopped at the door, ready to knock, when she stopped herself. She never knocked. Why start now? She opened the screen door, and walked inside. Maria was sitting at the table, reading the paper. "Hi Maria," Hannah said. "Oh, hi Hannah. Luis is still getting ready. This is the first time I've seen him take more than an hour and a half with a girl. And he yells at me for taking the time I do in the bathroom," She said with a laugh. "Yeah, guys are like that I guess," Hannah said taking a chair next to Maria, who had set the paper on the table. She took a sip of her coffee. "What movie are you going to see?" She asked. "Oh, I'm not sure. Luis was going to surprise me," She replied. "Oh," Maria took another sip, and she set the cup back on the table.
12311121.title: Good Neighborhood

123111211.content:
Just then, a door opened upstairs and a cloud of steam and cologne wafted down to the two ladies at the table. Maria and Hannah looked at eachother, wide eyed. Maria grinned. "An hour and a half," she whispered and giggled silently. Hannah could feel a blush creeping up her face, but she smiled back at Maria.

"Hey, Mama, did I hear Hannah down there?"

"Si, querido. She's been waiting." Maria teased.

"Okay, give me a minute." Luis's footsteps hammered the floor above; a minute later, he came downstairs.

Hannah turned to greet him, but the words froze in her throat. Loose jeans hung just right at his waist. A black muscle shirt was belted into those jeans and covered with a red rayon overshirt. Good clothes, but Luis always had priceless taste. What struck Hannah speechless was...well, she couldn't put her finger on it. His aura, maybe. Why hadn't she ever noticed how...male Luis looked with wet hair? Why hadn't she ever noticed the gold sparks in his coffee-brown eyes? Why had she never noticed his cologne, his own scent? She shook her head and smiled. "Get a grip," she thought, "He's still Luis."

"Hey," was what she actually said.

After a moment of silence ...Oh please let him be thinking the same sort of thing I just was, Hannah prayed... Luis smiled back. "Hey. Ready to go?"

"Yeah."

Luis nodded, then turned to hug his mother. " Hasta luego, mama. I'll be back late tonight."

"Before midnight." Maria said, fingercombing her son's hair.

"Before midnight. Te amo, mama. Buenos noches."

"Te amo, querido. Be good."

Luis bent to kiss his mother's cheek, then offered his arm to Hannah. Together they walked out to his car. "I figured we'd ride in style," he said, grinning and gesturing at the beat up Volkswagon.

Hannah laughed and patted the SuperBeetle's hood affectionately. "You be nice to the love bug. It's been nice to you."

Luis arched an eyebrow at her and smiled. She read his look and gave him her best Bruce Lee face. "Not what I meant. Be nice to me, too."

He grinned. "I promise not to hate you because you're beautiful."

They got into the car and set out for downtown. "So what are we going to see?" Hannah asked.

Luis shrugged. "I don't know. The multiplex has a fistful of new releases going, so I figured we'd hash it out when we got there. What're you in the mood for?"
123111211.title: Stunned...

1231112111.content:
Hannah replied somewhat ambiguously, not really wanting to commit to anything for fear of giving Luis a negative impression of her. It's not like they hadn't known each other all their lives, nor was it exactly that she thought that he would think badly of her for her choice of movies- they had argued about that countless times before. It was just that she felt rather awkward in a new situation. She was conscious of all the things that she had never bothered to consider when being out with Luis before, like Food-in-Teeth or Possible-Embarrassing-Substance-on-Pants Syndrome.

When they arrived at the movie theater, they had seen nearly all of the movies playing, though not necessarily together. They finally agreed on the only movie neither of them had seen, which, incidentally, turned out to be Luis's idea of a chick flick.

"I'd better not see anyone I know here!" Luis teased Hannah.

"Whatever!" Hannah laughed, and tagged Luis on the arm.

Luis bought the tickets and offered to buy Hannah some refreshments, but not wanting to risk bad breath or looking like a pig, and other assorted embarrassments associated with eating, Hannah thanked him anyway, but answered to the negative.

Luis picked out seats in the very back row of the theater, and as they sat waiting for the movie to begin, they laughed nervously about the fact that no one else appeared to be seeing the same movie that they were. Eventually what appeared to be two middle-aged women sat themselves in the middle of the theater.

"Darn, now I can't kiss you loud," Luis joked, winking at Hannah.

Hannah just blushed in return, and looked away, not realizing how appealing she was making herself to the guy whose gaze she had previously never been afraid to meet. She couldn't believe how nervous she was! Luis appeared to be completely at ease, but Hannah wasn't sure, and didn't know that she wanted to ask, for fear of what he might say. So instead, they sat quietly through the previews until the movie started.

Neither Hannah nor Luis touched the other during the entire first half of the movie, though neither could say that they didn't want to. Both stared straight ahead, and didn't move except for the occasional crossing or uncrossing of the legs. However, being something of a chick flick, the movie began to lean toward the sad side, a very endearing main character's death looming in the near future, and Hannah began to edge a little closer to Luis, who instinctively put his arm around her and pulled her close. They sat that way through the rest of the movie, and when the credits started to role, Luis gently kissed Hannah's forhead and stood up, taking her hand.

It was dark when they came out of the theater, and they walked hand in hand out to the old Lovebug, where he opened the door for her and then closed it behind her. When he got in the car, she smiled shyly at him, but was more silent than she had ever been at any point in her friendship with Luis.

"So, you hungry?" Luis asked, with a smile.

"Um, not really," replied Hannah, smiling back at him, "You?"

"Maybe we'll get something later," he told her, "But first, there's something I want to show you."

"What is it?" asked Hannah.

"You'll see," Luis replied mysteriously.

1231112112.content:

After a couple of minutes Hannah shoves her phone back into her pocket, sighing. She tried to picture what Luis would be doing- somehow, she can't imagine him posing nervously in front of the mirror for her. She smiled, so happy that both of their feeling are out in the open.

What's taking him? she thinks, about to get up and peek in the door, when she hears voices again. They are muffled and Hannah can only catch bits.

Yasmine? Who's Yasmine? Hannah wonders, listening intently.

Then she hears Luis. "...study..."

Hannah stares at the door, confused. A couple of seconds later, it opens and she jumps back. A girl with shoulder length sandy brown hair steps out, talking to Luis. Her olive skin shines and her blue eyes sparkle as she gushes about something or other.

12311121212.content:
"So.. you ready?" Luis asks, digging his hands into his pockets and sauntering forward.

Hannah flinches. Was that lopsided grin a result of spending time with Yasmine? She takes a deep breath and walks forward, quickly falling into step with Luis.

"Yeah.. so, what do you think we should see?" she says, trying in vain to meet his eyes and reignite the spark she knew they had.

"Um.. what about Restless?"

Hannah turns, feeling slightly surprised. I thought I knew Luis. she thinks. She knows a Luis that would have immediately fired back Hannah's question with an impish smile and an affectionate shove.

"Well?"

"Uh yeah, sure, why not? Not that into action though. I guess you know that."

"Yep." Luis offers a smile and a nod, then nonchalantly slips his phone out of his pocket. "Yasmine recommended it."

Yasmine recommended it. Hannah swallows the words she wants to say- words that would subtly insult Yasmine.

Luis's phone bleeps, before blurting out an obnoxious tune. Hannah bites her lip hard. A song she hates. A song her sister used to play on a loop. A mindless melody with squeaky vocals. A song he knows she hates.

Then he turns away slightly, tapping words quickly into his phone, tongue sticking out of the side of his mouth as if he was concentrating hard.

"Who is it?" Hannah doesn't want to know.

"Yaz."

Yaz. He calls her Yaz.

"So." Hannah sighs, as they turn a corner, away from Luis' street. "Yasmine." she stretched out the name. "She seemed pretty nice."

They turn the corner of Luis's street.

"Yeah, she's cool."

He begins tapping more words into the message, then with a push of a button sends it into Yasmine's hands.

"So, what were you guys studying?" Hannah asks. Another dull question.

"Oh, y'know." Another couple of letters appear on the screen. "Some science and history."

All I want is for him to speak to me without me asking him something. Hannah thinks in frustration.

"I think I recognise her from somewhere."

She doesn't. Who cares if I lie? All I want is a reply that doesn't sound like it's coming from a stone!

Luis turns his phone off and stuffs it back into his pocket. "Oh, really? Where?"

Hannah chews her lip, unsure. Should I? She opens and closes her mouth, hesitant, feeling slightly pathetic. How could she ever do that to Luis?

1231211.title: Hannah's

12312112.content:
Hannah prances up the stairs to her bedroom, plopping down onto her bed, running a hand along the silky purple cover. She was in deep thought about what Luis had mumbled before he left. She tried convincing herself that she had carelessly imagine what he had said, or had misheard him, but it was all clear what he said: I love you

The problem was, did she love him back? She had stumbled for words, that were in her mind, ready to say, but she couldn't bring herself to say them. Was that out of the embarrassment they had both encountered, or did she truly not mean it? Did she love her best buddy, Luis?

Hannah sighed, shook her head, and decided she hadn't time for deep thinking -- the inner-debate would have to wait. She checked her watch for the time -- 6:15! She had only an hour and fifteen minutes to get ready! Hannah sprang up from her purple bed-covers, and rushed to her dresser to pick out an outfit. What to wear, what to wear... the same old inner monologue idea that every girl gets when prepping for... well, anything. She eventually decided on a navy blue tank top, with a bright yellow, starred baggy over-shirt to wear over it. Without the tank top, it would hardly cover her cleavage and mid-section. She carefully picked a purple pair of skinny jeans to go along with it, green socks, and red Converse shoes.

After dressing into the outfit, she checked her watch again -- 6:45! It had taken her 30 minutes to choose and put on a pair of clothing? This was slightly longer a time than usual, but she justified it with the fact that she was going to a club of sorts, with tons of people to impress. After looking in a full-body mirror, she decided the outfit was wonderful. But the problem? Her messy, straight, auburn hair. A slight panic overcame her. She knew she could fix it to look perfect, but -- did it look that messy when she and Luis exchanged goodbyes? Or had it gotten messy from prancing upstairs and slamming down on the bed?

No matter, she decided, and headed off to the bathroom that she had the luxury of being located in her bedroom. Sometimes Hannah felt so lucky to have the things she did: Her own bedroom, her own bathroom... Luis. She tried to shake the thought from her head and grabbed her curling iron. It was time to get funky! Ten minutes later, her hair was sectioned into tight auburn spirals that looks full and shiny. She clapped and cheered at her success. Hannah returned to the full-body mirror to check herself out. Perfect, she decided, but she needed some makeup. Not too much, but maybe a little eyeliner, mascara, and eyeshadow.

She carefully picked out the best shade of purple and applied it lightly to her eyelids. After applying the shadow, she took the eyeliner pencil and neatly drew a thin black line on the edge of her upper eyelids. After applying the necessary amount of mascara, she checked the mirror once more, then the time -- 7:05! She silently applauded herself for finishing her hair and her makeup faster than her clothing. A few moments later, she heard a knock at the door downstairs.

She hopped down the stairs and to the front door. Of course, it was Luis -- who was jaw-dropped, looking her up and down, from her curled hair and makeup, to the red shoes over the green socks on her feet. Stunned, he said "You look... amazing." And Hannah could say the same about Luis.

He had a multi-colored long-sleeved shirt on, unbuttoned, and black dress pants, complimented with black dress shoes. His hair was green down with hair gel, and curled at the tip of his black hair. His brown eyes sparkled as he marveled at Hannah.

"Well, there's something we can agree with each other on. Now why don't we head on out?" They walked out the door, and Hannah closed it behind her, locking it with a key that she placed in her back pocket. "Let's go." She said. The two teenagers then disco-danced all the way to the car, laughing and giggling along the way.
***********

When they got to the disco, there were a ton of teenagers, ages 13-17, disco-dancing to songs like "Burn Baby Burn" and "Stayin' Alive".

After a glance to one another, they decided to dance with each.

"May I have this dance?" Luis asked in his best fake British accent, slowly extending his hand to Hannah, who agreed and took it. Inevitably, a slow song started playing -- You Don't Have to Say You Love Me by Dusty Springfield. They blushed and took each others hand, swaying to the music, Luis twirling Hannah around and around. Hannah giggled as he did, and dizzily stumbled into his arms, blushing as she stared up into his deep brown eyes.

1232211.content:
"Hi, Mr. Donovan. May I speak with Maggie, please? ... Thank you." In her life, Hannah had had two better-than-best friends. One, obviously, was Luis. The other was Magdalena Donovan. She and Maggie had hooked up when Hannah was a freshman. Maggie, a sophomore, had just moved to town and had a couple of classes with Hannah. They learned the ropes of the new high school together, watched eachother's backs back when both of them were not-so-popular. Made for a tight bond. As Hannah waited on the line, she realised how little she'd been talking to Maggie since Luis joined the football team. She wondered if Mags would even talk to her now... Then there was music on the other end of the line and Maggie's rough voice yelling to her dad that she had it.

"Hey, you got me. Who is it?"

"Hi, Maggie. It's Hannah. How's it going?"

"Woah! Drops of Jupiter indeed! So, did you fall from a shooting star or what, boo?"

It took a second for Hannah to translate the question out of Mag's inimitable slang. "Not fallen yet, but in the process. That's half the trouble." It was funny: In all of Hannah's memories, the things Maggie said sounded normal. Was this what she'd sounded like her freshman year? No wonder no one understood her...

"Should've known that's why you'd call." Maggie snorted a little bitterly and then coughed. "Hang on." The music--some unknown jazz/rock group that Maggie had taken as her personal cause, unless Hannah missed her guess--dropped a few notches and changed songs. "So," Maggie said when she picked the phone back up, "What's your trouble?"

"Look, I'm sorry if I've been out of touch the past few. It's just been... hectic." This wasn't as easy as Hannah'd thought it would be.

Maggie's hissed laughter crackled over the phone line. "No worries, boo. It's all good. You lose track of time with the flock, but those who watch against wolves do know the hour. So straight, what's up?"

"You remember Luis?"

A slightly derisive "MMM Hmm."

"Well...things are changing with me and him, and I don't know if they should or what to do or anything." Hannah proceeded to fill Maggie in on the events of the past few weeks, especially last night and "Who'll save me from you?". By the end of it, the music had stopped entirely and Hannah could sense Maggie actually considering her trouble.

"So, long story straight, your long-standing brother-in-arms now wants to be the long-standing brother with charms, non?"

"Oui."

"And you, though you would not be averse to the proposition, don't want to lose your closest ever friend. So you're scared. Have I got it so far?"

"Yeah."

Maggie took a long breath, and Hannah wondered what kind of incense her amiga was burning tonight. "It's sandalwood," Maggie answered, and Hannah wondered if she'd asked the question out loud.

"A'ight. Look, boo, the best I've got is that you've got to listen to your heart...and listen to his, if you two are that tight. If you want to pursue something a little...more...and he does, too, then do. You got an itch, go scratch. Take some time, sound him out, and then step to the real. You might be good for him. Cool?"

Hannah smiled at the phone. "Yeah. Cool. Hey, Mags?"

"Yo?"

"Thank you. I mean, I know I haven't been all that great to you lately, and it's really big of you to help me out like this. Especially since I know you don't dig Luis too much. Thanks."

"No prob, boo. I've always got your back. All you got to do is ask."

They sat in silence a while, listening to the new album Maggie'd put on. The guy was playing guitar like no one Hannah'd ever heard. "I can't be her angel now," he sang, "You know it's not my place to hold her down. And it's hard for me to take a stand, but I would take her any way I can..."

"I've got to go, babe." Hannah said to Maggie. "Got to call somebody, even some things out."

"Yeah. You stay in touch, eh, boo? Miss you."

"I'll stay in touch."

"Call me if he needs his six kicked."

Hannah laughed. "Only after I've already done it!"

"'S my girl. Be good."

"Or at least good at it."

Hannah hung up the phone with the song going through her head. She leaned back against the wall and sighed. "This shouldn't be this hard..." she murmured to no one as she closed her eyes...


~~side note: lyrics (c) John Mayer, 1999~~

'Don't go.' He whispered so softly, his eyes deep pools of chocolate brown looking up at me with that fear I did not wish to let down so hard as to run again.
'Luis, Luis we can't do this. We just can't,' I ran my fingers through my hair maturely as a look of confusion spread across his perfect, palette pale face. 'I don't want things to change, you know, between us.'
'They already have.' He mumbled shoving both hands deep into his pockets turning away from me and for once being the one to leave me standing. Suddenly I felt the gut wrenching pain. It was that moment I swore never to run from his eyes again.
'Luis, Luis wait!'
123221212.title: Understanding a friend

1232212122.content:
"Nothing. Nevermind." She whispered.
The door clicked as it shut and Hannah's hands fell away, holding her stomach instead. There was a churning, twisting feeling inside her as tears came to her eyes for the second time that day. Before she could throw the door open and run after Luis, she turned the other way and ran as fast as she could to her room. After tripping over her own feet and bumping into her brother, she finally made it. Closing the door, she collapsed onto her bed.
"Damn it!" Hannah shouted into her pillow. She absently wondered if she was being dramatic, but she really couldn't help it.
Imagining it...Luis never calling her Hannah-Banana again, no more nights at the Diner, no more innocent teasing wih her best friend...
Hannah let out a loud sob, squeezing her eyes shut.

Just then, there was a knock at her door.
"Hey Hann...can I come in?" Her older brother asked.
1232212122.title: It Can't Change

12322122.content:
Hannah tried to compose herself as she returned the phone to it's cradle on the wall. She heard the slight commotion as Luis's voice mingled with her brother's at the door. Quickly Hannah tried to erase the telltale signs that she had been crying - something he already knew anyhow.

"Hannah?" The door to the kitchen swung open and there he was. His dark eyes looked at her with concern. "What's wrong?"

She knew her face was burning a bright red as she spoke, but she tried not to let her emotions get the better of her. 'Think,' Hannah tried to tell her brain. 'Think of an excuse.'

"Um.. Onions!!" The word was blurted out before she could stop it. "I was - uh - just uh, chopping up some onions, and they - uh - well.. ya know, my eyes. And then I thought I'd give you a call... Maybe we could do something. Watch TV, or.. something?"

The feeling of humiliation swept over her. Onions? Couldn't she have at least come up with something better? Or, at the very least, not have sounded so stupid? Why was this becoming so difficult?

Luis glanced behind Hannah at the spotless kitchen, and eyed her carefully. He knew something was up, but obviously she didn't want to speak of it. He tried to remember what she had said.

'Should I question her about what's bothering her,' he wondered, 'or just ignore it, and let her say something when she's ready?'

Before he could decide, Hannah moved, and flung open a cupboard, pulling out a bag of potato chips. "Let's go watch a movie." She headed towards the door.

"Hannah?"
12322122.title: Onions and Potato Chips

"What Luis?" hannah asked already knowing what the question was going to be...but her answer she still didn't know what to say in response to THAT question, the one that would change their whole freindship. Hannah directed her attention to Luis.

123222121.content:
Hannah was early home because her teacher in the her last class gave them a break and decided that they should call it a day.
This is nice, she thought. I could prepare for the movies tonight. Then her thoughts run back to her, why would I want to prepare for tonight?, she ask herself and shook her head in confusion.
She went upstairs and put her bookbag down and flopped herself on her bed. What is going on?,she asked again. And why am I having these thoughts?, she added. She became scared of what this thoughts make her feel. She closed her eyes and all Hannah could see is Luis cocoa-dazzling eyes.
"Stop it!", she blurted in annoyance with herself and forced herself up to her cabinet and look for something to wear. For the first time she noticed her dark green dress, that will elegantly fit her for the occasion, not too casual yet not too "dressy".

*******

Hannah looked at herself in the mirror, she was all dressed up and ready to go. Luis called and he said he will pick her up in 5 minutes.
This is not me, she said to herself. I put on make up just for him and even bothered to style my hair just for him, what am I doing?, she sighed and shook her head for the second time since she got home.
Should I really go out with him tonight?

1232221212112112.content:
At the park, Luis almost leaped out of the car. Hannah's brain started to panic. "He can't even stand to be around me! What am I doing? Did I offend him? Am I being too forward? Calm down, girl! He's just your best friend! You've known each other forever- calm down!"
Suddenly, she realized that Luis was holding the door open for her; eagerly waiting for her to get out. Hannah felt her face flush in the dark. All he had wanted to do was open the door for her and she had started thinking he was avoiding her. It was a VERY good thing that he could hardly see her face.
"Hannah? Are you going to get out of the car?" Luis' face peered anxiously at her. He seemed uncertain how what to do now that her door was open.
"Oh, of course!" Hannah's face went even redder as she hurried scrambled out of the car. Since when had he ever treated her like a lady instead of a best friend? Hannah pushed the thought out of her mind.

1232221212112112.title: Arriving at the Park

12322212121121121.content:
"How does a walk sound?"
"Lovely."
They walked for five or six minutes before either of them said anything, and when they did, it was simultaneous. "Luis, I--,"
"Babe, can--,"
They laughed and turned to look at each other. "You first." she said quickly.
"Okay, can I ask you something?"
"Sure," she said, her heart starting to race.
"Did I ever tell you about my father? Anything about him?"
"No, why?"
"Well, he was in the military," he led her over to a bench and they sat down next to each other. She shivered, so he held her close. "He was in the air force, a really high ranking officer and his plane was shot down. They never found it. He could be alive or dead, a prisoner, or a body, and we wouldn't know the difference."
"Oh my god, Luis ! Why didn't you ever tell me?"
"Well, I didn't know my self until i was ten, until then my mom had just told me he died. But i figured it was time someone else knew what a great man he was."
"Thank you for telling me that. I feel like I know you even better now."
"I'm glad you know." They sat for a while, half-cuddling half sitting close together. After quite some time Luis said to her, "Are you cold?"
"Freezing."
They both laughed quietly, and got up to walk back to his car. When the car was warmer, She removed her coat. Luis caught himself staring, and started to drive away. "What's the rush, big boy?" she asked laughing.
"Oh..."
